metadata.title: miR‐382‐5p promotes porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) replication by negatively regulating the induction of type I interferon
metadata.author: Xiaobo Chang, Xibao Shi, Xiaozhuan Zhang, Jing Chen, Xiaomin Fan, Yuanhao Yang, Li Wang, Aiping Wang, Ruiguang Deng, Enmin Zhou, Gaiping Zhang

metadata.abstract: Previous studies have indicated that inhibition of type I interferon production may be an important reason for porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) to achieve immune escape, revealing the mechanism of inhibiting the production of type I interferon will help design novel strategies for controlling PRRS. Here, we found that PRRSV infection upregulated the expression of miR382-5p, which in turn inhibited polyI:C-induced the production of type I interferon by targeting heat shock protein 60 (HSP60), thus facilitating PRRSV replication in MARC-145 cells. Furthermore, we found that HSP60 could interact with mitochondrial antiviral signaling protein (MAVS), an important signal transduction protein for inducing production of type I interferon, and promote polyI:C-mediated the production of type I interferon in a MAVS-dependent manner. Finally, we also found that HSP60 could inhibit PRRSV replication in a MAVS-dependent manner, which indicated that HSP60 was a novel antiviral protein against PRRSV replication. In conclusion, the study demonstrated that miR-382-5p was upregulated during PRRSV infection and may promote PRRSV replication by negatively regulating the production of type I interferon, which also indicated that miR-382-5p and HSP60 might be the potential therapeutic targets for anti-PRRSV.

author_conclusions: In conclusion, we have demonstrated that PRRSV infection upregulated the expression of miR-382-5p, which in turn could facilitate PRRSV replication and inhibit the production of type I interferon by targeting HSP60 (Figure 9). And we also found that HSP60 could promote the production of type I interferon, interact with MAVS and inhibit PRRSV replication in a MAVS-dependent manner. These data indicated that miR-382-5p was a host component upregulated by PRRSV to regulate PRRSV replication and HSP60 was a novel antiviral protein against PRRSV.

introduction:
Porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV), a small enveloped virus including a single positive-strand RNA genome and belonging to Arteriviridae family,[1] with highest mutant rate of all known RNA viruses,[2] causes reproductive disorders in sows and respiratory distress in piglets and is considered as one of the most economically significant pathogens worldwide.[3] PRRSV consists of an enveloped approximately 15 kb RNA genome containing at least ten open reading frames (ORFs).[4,5]

Type I interferons (IFNs) play key roles in antiviral responses. After the virus invades the cell, the viral nucleic acid and other pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) could be recognized by cellular pattern-recognition receptors (PRRs) such as retinoic acid-inducible gene-I (RIG-I)-like receptors and Toll-Like receptors (TLRs). Then, TLRs through binding myeloid differentiation factor 88 (MyD88) or Toll/ IL-1 receptor domain-containing adaptor protein inducing IFNβ (TRIF), while RIG-I or melanoma differentiation-associated gene 5 (MDA5) via binding to their adaptor protein mitochondrial antiviral signaling protein (MAVS) (also known as VISA), transmits signals to TANK-binding kinase 1 (TBK1) and I kappa B kinase ε (IKK-ε). And then, TBK1/ IKK-ε activates IRF-3, IRF-7, nuclear factor kappa B (NF-κB), and other transcription factors, and induces type I interferon transcription. Finally, type I interferons bind to IFN-α/β r eceptors on the cell surface, causing receptor dimerization, and eventually inducing the production of a large number of IFN-stimulated genes that could inhibit or eliminate the virus.[6,7]
discussion: The main characteristic of PRRSV infection is that it could cause immunosuppression, persistent infection, and secondary infection, resulting in huge economic losses to the pig industry.[43-45] Previous studies have indicated that type I interferons have an antiviral effect against PRRSV.[46] MiRNAs are an abundant class of highly conserved, small, non-coding RNAs, and play critical roles in the regulation of diverse biological processes, including immune responses.[47,48] It has been shown that many miRNAs, including miR-21, miR-31, miR-182, miR-221-5p, miR-1248, miR-146a, participate in the regulation of type I interferon signaling.[20,23,49-53] In this study, we found that miR-382-5p was upregulated by PRRSV (Figure 1), and acted as a novel miRNA that negatively regulated the production of type I interferon (Figure 3) and promoted PRRSV replication (Figure 2). MiRNAs function as important posttranscriptional regulators and could be as the potential therapeutic targets for disease treatment, so miR-382-5p might be a potential therapeutic target for anti-PRRSV.

Abstract: Previous studies have indicated that inhibition of type I interferon production may be an important reason for porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) to achieve immune escape, revealing the mechanism of inhibiting the production of type I interferon will help design novel strategies for controlling PRRS. Here, we found that PRRSV infection upregulated the expression of miR382-5p, which in turn inhibited polyI:C-induced the production of type I interferon by targeting heat shock protein 60 (HSP60), thus facilitating PRRSV replication in MARC-145 cells. Furthermore, we found that HSP60 could interact with mitochondrial antiviral signaling protein (MAVS), an important signal transduction protein for inducing production of type I interferon, and promote polyI:C-mediated the production of type I interferon in a MAVS-dependent manner. Finally, we also found that HSP60 could inhibit PRRSV replication in a MAVS-dependent manner, which indicated that HSP60 was a novel antiviral protein against PRRSV replication. In conclusion, the study demonstrated that miR-382-5p was upregulated during PRRSV infection and may promote PRRSV replication by negatively regulating the production of type I interferon, which also indicated that miR-382-5p and HSP60 might be the potential therapeutic targets for anti-PRRSV.

1 | INTRODUCTION: Porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV), a small enveloped virus including a single positive-strand RNA genome and belonging to Arteriviridae family,[1] with highest mutant rate of all known RNA viruses,[2] causes reproductive disorders in sows and respiratory distress in piglets and is considered as one of the most economically significant pathogens worldwide.[3] PRRSV consists of an enveloped approximately 15 kb RNA genome containing at least ten open reading frames (ORFs).[4,5]

Type I interferons (IFNs) play key roles in antiviral responses. After the virus invades the cell, the viral nucleic acid and other pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) could be recognized by cellular pattern-recognition receptors (PRRs) such as retinoic acid-inducible gene-I (RIG-I)-like receptors and Toll-Like receptors (TLRs). Then, TLRs through binding myeloid differentiation factor 88 (MyD88) or Toll/ IL-1 receptor domain-containing adaptor protein inducing IFNβ (TRIF), while RIG-I or melanoma differentiation-associated gene 5 (MDA5) via binding to their adaptor protein mitochondrial antiviral signaling protein (MAVS) (also known as VISA), transmits signals to TANK-binding kinase 1 (TBK1) and I kappa B kinase ε (IKK-ε). And then, TBK1/ IKK-ε activates IRF-3, IRF-7, nuclear factor kappa B (NF-κB), and other transcription factors, and induces type I interferon transcription. Finally, type I interferons bind to IFN-α/β r eceptors on the cell surface, causing receptor dimerization, and eventually inducing the production of a large number of IFN-stimulated genes that could inhibit or eliminate the virus.[6,7]

Previous studies have shown that PRRSV could inhibit type I interferon transcription,[8-10] while pretreatment of porcine alveolar macrophages (PAMs) or MARC-145 cells with type I Interferon could significantly inhibit PRRSV replication, and the results in vivo were consistent with those in vitro,[11,12] which indicated that inhibition of type I interferon transcription (production) may be an important reason for PRRSV to achieve immune escape.

In fact, in the long-term coevolution of virus and host, regulating and using host components to escape host immune clearance is the common strategy for many viruses.[13-16] MicroRNA (miRNA), a length of 21 to 25 nt non-coding RNA, is an important endogenous regulatory factor at the posttranscriptional level in animals and plants. The seed sequence (usually 6 to 8 bases) of miRNA binds to the 3′-UTR (5′-UTR of a few target genes) of the corresponding target gene to suppress translation or induce mRNA degradation of the target gene.[17,18] It has reported that a large number of miRNAs could regulate the transcription and function of type I interferon.[19-26] And our previous study found that miR373 was upregulated by PRRSV and negatively regulated the
CHANG et al.
production of type I interferon by targeting nuclear factor IA (NFIA) and NFIB that could bind to the IFN-β promoter.[27]

Heat shock protein 60 (HSP60), also known as HSPD1, is a molecular chaperone classically described as a mitochondrial protein.[28] HSP60 can transiently associate with endoplasmic reticulum (ER) membrane or it could also be an itinerant ER protein.[29] It has been demonstrated that in normal conditions, HSP60 is mainly located in the mitochondria of eukaryotes, and 15%-20% of HSP60 is located at extra-mitochondrial sites, namely, in the cytosol, cell surface, mitochondrial outer membrane, cytosolic vesicles plasma membrane, endoplasmic reticulum, and peroxisomes.[30] HSP60 is an ATPdependent protein with ATPase activity and it can assist folding processes and conformational changes in many proteins.[31] Besides, HSP60 is a linking molecule in intercellular immune networks and functions as a highly connected chaperone with links to most cellular proteins.[32]

In this study, we found that miR-382-5p was upregulated by PRRSV, and could inhibit type I interferon production and promote PRRSV replication. Besides, we clarified a novel mechanism by HSP60 regulates type I interferon signaling and PRRSV replication. We revealed that HSP60 could positively regulate MAVS-mediated type I IFN signaling and interact with MAVS, and the antiviral activity of HSP60 is dependent on MAVS.

MARC-145 cells, human embryonic kidney (HEK) 293T cells, baby hamster kidney (BHK)-21 cells were cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (DMEM) supplemented with 10% of fetal bovine serum (FBS), 100 U/ml penicillin, and 100 μg/mL streptomycin. All cells were incubated at 37°C in an incubator with 5% of CO2. PRRSV strain BJ-4 (GenBank No.AF331831), a low pathogenic PRRSV strain, was a kind gift from Prof. Hanchun Yang (China Agricultural University).

PRRSV N protein antibody was purchased from GeneTex (Alton Pkwy Irvine,

The precursor DNA sequence of miR-382-5p was cloned into the vector pcDNA6.2 (Invitrogen) to construct the plasmid pcDNA6.2-miR-382-5p (p6.2-miR-382-5p). The oligonucleotides of 3′UTR and mutant 3′UTR of HSP60 were synthesized by Sangon Biotech (Shanghai, China), and then were cloned into psiCHECK-2 (Promega, Madison, WI, USA) using the XhoI and NotI restriction sites, and the constructed plasmids were termed as HSP60-3′UTR and Mut-HSP60-3′UTR, respectively. The cDNA of HSP60 was cloned into pCMV-Myc (Beyotime, Shanghai, China)), which was named as HSP60Myc. The cDNAs of MAVS, IRF3, and TBK1 were cloned into pCMV-Flag (Beyotime), which were termed as MAVSFlag, IRF3-Flag, and TBK1-Flag, respectively. The cDNA of MAVS and C-terminal deletion of MAVS (MAVS-1), N-terminal deletions of MAVS (MAVS-2 and MAVS-3) were cloned into p3×Flag-CMV-7.1 (Sigma-Aldrich), which were termed as MAVS-3×Flag, MAVS-1-3×Flag, MAVS2-3×Flag, MAVS-3-3×Flag. All primers used are listed in Table 1.

The plasmid p-284 Luc, an IFN-β promoter reporter plasmid, has been constructed as our previous described.[10] The pRL-TK (Promega), containing a Renilla-luciferase reporter gene, was used as an internal control in dual luciferase reporter assay system.

RNeasy Mini Kit (Qiagen) was used for the extraction of cellular total RNA and reverse transcription was accomplished with PrimeScript RT Master Mix (Perfect Real Time) (Takara, Kyoto, Japan) according to the manufacturer's protocol. And the quantitative real time polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) was performed by using a Fast Start Universal SYBR Green Master (ROX) Kit (Roche, Basel, Switzerland) on a 7500 fast RT-PCR system (Applied Biosystems). Primers were shown in Table 2. Relative analysis of gene expression was evaluated using the 2−ΔΔCT method,[33] in which target gene expression was normalized by glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH) expression.

Quantification of miRNAs was performed by quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) using miRNA analysis kits (Qiagen) according to the manufacturer's instructions. Relative analysis of miRNA was also evaluated using the 2− ΔΔCT method, while U6 snRNA was used in place of GAPDH as the internal control.

MARC-145 Cells or 293T cells in 24-well plates were transfected with miR-382-5p mimic, miR-382-5p inhibitor, or indicated expression plasmids, and luciferase reporter plasmids by using Lipofectamine 2000 transfection reagent. Thirty-six hours later, the cells were transfected with polyI:C (10 μg/mL). Then, 12 hours later, the cells were harvested for luciferase activity assay by using dual-luciferase reporter assay system (Promega).

The specific siRNAs targeting the indicated genes and the control siRNA (siNC) were synthesized by GenePharma (Shanghai, China), and the siRNAs were listed in Table 3. The transfection assay of siRNA was performed as the previously described.[34] Briefly, MARC-145 cells were transfected with 50 nM of siRNA by using Lipofectamine RNAiMAX transfection reagent according to the manufacturer's instruction. Twenty-four hours later, the cells were infected with PRRSV at a multiplicity of infection (MOI) of 0.1. And 2 hours later, the cells were cultured with the fresh DMEM containing 2% of FBS. Finally, the cells or the supernatants were harvested at the indicated times for further analysis.

BHK-21 cells were cotransfected with HSP60-Myc and MAVS-3×Flag or the corresponding control vector. Thirty-six hours later, the cells were fixed with 4% of paraformaldehyde for 20 minute, and then, the cells treated with 0.2% of Triton X-100 for 15 minute and were blocked with 5% of skim milk for 2 hours at room temperature. The cells were then incubated with the respective primary antibodies and FITC-conjugated or TRITC-conjugated secondary antibodies, followed by visualization with confocal microscopy (ZEISS LSM 800).

Our previous report has shown that miR-382-5p was a PRRSV-downregulated miRNA by the high-throughput sequencing of small RNAs from MARC-145 cells infected with PRRSV.[27] To confirm the result, a time-course assay and a dose-dependent assay were performed by qPCR. To our surprise, the results in Figure 1A showed that the expression levels of miR-382-5p were increased in MARC-145 cells infected with PRRSV and reached a peak at 24 hours postinfection. In addition, the expression levels of miR-382-5p were higher in MARC-145 cells infected with PRRSV at higher MOI than that at lower MOI, which indicated that PRRSV infection increased the expression of miR-382-5p in a dosedependent manner in MARC-145 cells (Figure 1B). These results suggested that PRRSV upregulated miR-382-5p expression.

Virus titration was determined using MARC-145 cells as previously described.[34] Briefly, MARC-145 cells, grown in 96-well plates, were infected with 10-fold serial dilution of samples. After 1 hour incubation at 37°C, the supernatants were replaced with fresh DMEM containing 2% of FBS. Then, five days postinfection, the PRRSV titers were determined by the 50% of tissue culture infected dose (TCID50) according to the Reed-Muench's method.[35]

It has reported that miRNAs produced by both viruses and their hosts can positively or negatively influence viral replication.[36] To determine whether miR-382-5p could regulate PRRSV replication, MARC-145 cells were transfected with

miR-382-5p mimic, negative control mimic (NC-mimic), miR-382-5p inhibitor, or NC-inhibitor, and then, the cells were infected with PRRSV. And 24 hours later, the RNA levels of PRRSV were determined by qPCR and the PRRSV titers were determined by TCID50, while N protein expression levels of PRRSV were detected by western blotting. The results in Figure 2 showed that miR-382-5p mimic could enhance the RNA levels of PRRSV (Figure 2A), the PRRSV titers (Figure 2C), and PRRSV N protein levels (Figure 2E,F), while miR-382-5p inhibitor decreased the RNA levels of PRRSV (Figure 2B), the PRRSV titers (Figure 2D), and PRRSV N protein levels (Figure 2G,H), which indicated that miR-382-5p promoted PRRSV replication. To confirm the above results, we also used p6.2-miR-382-5p in place of miR382-5p mimic and obtained similar results (data not shown).

MiRNAs function as regulators of cellular processes such as development, differentiation, growth, homeostasis, stress responses, apoptosis, and immune responses.[37,38] So, we wonder whether miR-382-5p upregulated by PRRSV could inhibit the production of type I interferon. The results in Figure 3 showed that miR-382-5p mimic could significantly inhibit ployI:C-induced IFN-β promoter activity (Figure 3A) and downregulate ployI:C-induced the mRNA levels of INF-β (Figure 3B), while miR-382-5p inhibitor could enhance ployI:C-induced IFN-β promoter activity (Figure 3C) and upregulate the mRNA levels of INF-β (Figure 3D). These results demonstrated that
miR-382-5p could negatively regulate the induction of type I interferon.

It has been reported that miRNAs play key roles in the regulation of cellular process depending on its targeting of specific genes.[39] And then, we investigated potential target genes of miR-382-5p. We used TargetScan, PicTar, and miRPathDB softwares to predict the candidate target genes of miR-382-5p, and nineteen candidate genes were chosen for further screening. However, the results indicated that the mRNA levels of X-linked DEAD-box RNA helicase DDX3 (DDX3X), HSP60, ubiquitin-specific peptidase 8 (USP8), Fas associated via death domain (FADD), and S-phase kinase associated protein 1 (SKP1) decreased in cells transfected with miR-382-5p mimic (Figure 4A), and increased in cells transfected with miR-382-5p inhibitor (Figure 4B). Next, knockdown of DDX3X, HSP60, USP8, FADD (Figure 4C,D) could increase the RNA levels of PRRSV, while only overexpression of HSP60 could downregulate the RNA levels of PRRSV (Figure 4E), which indicated that HSP60 may be an important target gene for miR-382-5p to promote PRRSV replication. Previous studies have shown that HSP60 was a target gene of miR-382-5p,40 and we confirmed the result in the study (see detail in Figure S1).

In order to further confirm that HSP60 is a host endogenous protein that antagonizes PRRSV replication, MARC145 cells were transfected with specific siRNA of HSP60 (siHSP60), which could efficiently reduce the HSP60 expression (Figure 4F,G), and then, the cells were infected with PRRSV for 24 hours, 36 hours, or 48 hours. The results showed that the N protein levels (Figure 4F,H), the RNA levels of PRRSV (Figure 4I) and virus titers (Figure 4J) were significantly increased in cells transfected with siHSP60 at all examined time points (24 hours, 36 hours, 48 hours) postinfection.

Finally, MARC-145 cells were transfected with HSP60Myc, which could express the HSP60 protein (Figure 4K), and then, the cells were infected with PRRSV for different times as indicated. The results showed that overexpression of HSP60 markedly reduced the N protein levels (Figure 4K,L), the RNA levels of PRRSV (Figure 4M), and virus titers (Figure 4N) at 24, 36, and 48 hpi. In conclusion, these data indicated that HSP60 was an antiviral protein against PRRSV.
3.5  |  HSP60 promotes the production of type I interferon in a MAVS-dependent manner

Now that miR-382-5p could inhibit the production of type I interferon and HSP60 was the target gene of miR-382-5p, we wonder whether HSP60 regulated the transcription of type I interferon. The results in Figure 5 showed that overexpression of HSP60 could increase polyI:C-induced IFN-β promoter activity (Figure 5A) and transcriptional levels of IFN-β (Figure 5B). Conversely, downregulation of HSP60

PolyI:C could be recognized by TLR3 or RIG-I, and then, TLR3 recruits TRIF and RIG-I recruits MAVS to phosphorylate IRF3 and finally activate type I IFN signaling pathway. And it has been documented that PRRSV infection suppressed the production of IFN-β primarily by interfering with the MAVS activation in the RIG-I signaling pathway.[9] So, we wonder whether HSP60 participated in MAVS-mediated production of IFN-β. The results showed that HSP60 enhanced MAVS-mediated IFN-β promoter activity (Figure 5E) and the transcription levels of IFN-β (Figure 5F). Subsequently, MARC-145 cells were transfected with MAVS, p-284, and different concentrations of HSP60, and we found that HSP60 increased MAVS-mediated IFN-β promoter activity (Figure 5G) and the transcriptional levels of IFN-β (Figure 5H) in a dose-dependent manner. In addition, HSP60 could also upregulate MAVS-induced the mRNA transcriptional levels of the IFN stimulated genes such as ISG15 and ISG56 (see detail in Figure S2). Thus, the above results strongly implied that HSP60 enhanced the MAVS-mediated the production and response of type I IFN.

Since HSP60 could increase the production of MAVSmediated type I interferon, we then determined whether HSP60 is associated with MAVS. Endogenous co-immunoprecipitation assays (co-IP) assays were performed using

MARC-145 cells and the results showed that HSP60 interacted with MAVS (Figure 6A,B). Subsequently, exogenous co-IP assays were performed in 293T cells and the results showed that the Myc-tagged HSP60 specifically interacted with Flag-tagged MAVS (Figure 6C,D). To further confirm the interaction existed between HSP60 and MAVS, confocal microscopy analyses were performed. Consistent with the results of Co-IP, HSP60 colocalized with MAVS (Figure 6E). Moreover, to determine the functions of MAVS domains[41,42] in binding with HSP60, a series of deletion mutants of MAVS were generated (Figure 6F). In the assays of Co-IP, HSP60 only interacted with full length MAVS, but not with deletion mutants of MAVS (Figure 6G), which indicated that the caspase activation and recruitment domain (CARD), the proline-rich domain and transmembrane (TM) domain of MAVS were all required for its interaction with HSP60.

HSP60 could interact with MAVS and enhance the MAVSmediated production of type I interferon, we then determined whether MAVS was essential for HSP60 to enhance polyI:C-mediated the production of type I interferon. MARC-145 cells were transfected with siRNAs of MAVS and HSP60Myc, with or without p-284 and pRL-TK, and then, 36 hours later, the cells were stimulated with polyI:C. The results in Figure 7 showed that HSP60 could not promote polyI:C-mediated the production of type I IFN upon silencing of MAVS.
So, the data indicated that HSP60 promotes the production of type I interferon in a MAVS-dependent manner.

In view of the fact that HSP60 enhanced polyI:C-mediated the production of type I IFN in a MAVS-dependent manner, we wonder whether HSP60 inhibited PRRSV replication was also dependent on the help of MAVS. MARC-145 cells were transfected with siRNAs of MAVS (siMAVS), and then, the cells were transfected with HSP60-Myc, and 24 hours later, the cells were infected with PRRSV, and another 24 hours later, the cells were collected for the further detection. As shown in Figure 8, HSP60 could not decrease the N protein levels (Figure 8A), PRRSV RNA levels (Figure 8B), and PRRSV titers (Figure 8C) in MARC-145 cells transfected
with siMAVS. These data suggested that the anti-PRRSV activity of HSP60 required the involvement of MAVS.
4 | DISCUSSION: The main characteristic of PRRSV infection is that it could cause immunosuppression, persistent infection, and secondary infection, resulting in huge economic losses to the pig industry.[43-45] Previous studies have indicated that type I interferons have an antiviral effect against PRRSV.[46] MiRNAs are an abundant class of highly conserved, small, non-coding RNAs, and play critical roles in the regulation of diverse biological processes, including immune responses.[47,48] It has been shown that many miRNAs, including miR-21, miR-31, miR-182, miR-221-5p, miR-1248, miR-146a, participate in the regulation of type I interferon signaling.[20,23,49-53] In this study, we found that miR-382-5p was upregulated by PRRSV (Figure 1), and acted as a novel miRNA that negatively regulated the production of type I interferon (Figure 3) and promoted PRRSV replication (Figure 2). MiRNAs function as important posttranscriptional regulators and could be as the potential therapeutic targets for disease treatment, so miR-382-5p might be a potential therapeutic target for anti-PRRSV.

Our previous results of small RNA deep sequencing of MARC-145 cells infected with PRRSV for 24 hours had shown that miR-382-5p was downregulated by PRRSV infection. However, the results in the present study showed that the expression levels of miR-382-5p were up-regulated following PRRSV infection, with maximum changes at 24 hours postinfection (Figure 1A), and PRRSV infection increased miR-382-5p expression in a dose-dependent manner in MARC-145 cells (Figure 1B), which indicated that the results about the expression levels of miR-382-5p from previous small RNA deep sequencing may be not correct.

To date, only one article has reported the relationship between miR-382-5p and virus replication, that is, the expression of miR-382 has positively correlated with the viral load of human immunodeficiency virus-1 (HIV) among long term non-progressors (LTNPs).[54] To our knowledge, our study suggested for the first time that miR-382-5p could promote the replication of PRRSV.

Previous studies have shown that HSP60 was the target gene of miR-382-5p40 and HSP60 was involved in the production of type I interferon since it could interact with activated IRF3.55 In our study, in addition to reconfirming that HSP60 was a target gene of miR-382-5p (Figure S1), there were four other new discoveries about HSP60 in this study. First, HSP60 could interact with MAVS (Figure 6C), which was an important signal transduction protein that activated IRF3 and NF-κB, and induced the production of type

I interferon.[56-58] The second novel result was that HSP60 promoted the production of type I interferon in a MAVSdependent manner (Figure 7). The third new result was that HSP60 was a novel antiviral protein against PRRSV replication (Figure 4). It is known that HSP60 plays a significant role in chaperone activity and protein folding,[59,60] and previous reports about the relationship between HSP60 and virus replication have shown that HSP60 could act as an important factor for viral replication.[61-65] Here, we found that overexpression of HSP60 could inhibit PRRSV replication in MARC-145 cells, and knockdown of HSP60 could promote PRRSV replication (Figure 8), which indicated that HSP60 was an antiviral protein against PRRSV replication. And it was the first time to give the sufficient evidence that HSP60 was an antiviral protein. The fourth novel result was that HSP60 inhibits PRRSV replication needs the help of MAVS, which indicated that MAVS-mediated type I interferon pathway may play an important role for HSP60 to inhibit PRRSV replication.

It has been reported that HSP60 promotes the TNF-αmediated activation of the IKK/NF-kB pathway via direct interaction with IKKα/β in the cytoplasm.[66] And HSP60 also could facilitate the phosphorylation and dimerization of IRF3, and interact with activated IRF3.55 In this study, HSP60 enhanced MAVS-mediated type I interferon signaling and interacted with MAVS. It is known that upon binding viral RNA, RIG-I and MDA5 are recruited to MAVS. MAVS forms large prion-like polymers that act as central platforms for the recruitment of downstream signaling components such as TRAF2/3/5/6, TBK1, and IKK complexes, leading to the activation of IRF3 and NF-κB and the induction of antiviral genes.[67] Additionally, HSP60 is a node in intracellular molecular networks, and a linking molecule in intercellular immune networks.[32] So, HSP60 might act as a critical regulator in MAVS-mediated downstream antiviral immune responses.

Mitochondrial antiviral signaling protein is a critical adaptor in RLR signaling pathway that links upstream recognition of viral RNA to downstream signal transduction in the antiviral response.[68] Upon RIG-I/MDA5 activation, MAVS forms large prion-like aggregates. MAVS aggregation is considered to be a hallmark of its activation and to be essential for its antiviral function.[69] Ubiquitination of RIG-I was shown to be a critical element for it to activate MAVS, RIG-I binds to unanchored lysine-63 (K63) polyubiquitin chains and that this binding is important for MAVS aggregation and activation.[70] TRIM31 was recruited to mitochondria, where it interacted with MAVS and catalyzed the K63-linked polyubiquitination of Lys[10], Lys[311], and Lys[461] on MAVS. These modifications increased the MAVS activation and downstream antiviral signaling.[71] Besides, SNX8 was reported to be associated with MAVS and increased the aggregation of MAVS.[67] Given that the role of Hsp[60] in RLRs or MAVS-mediated upstream

In conclusion, we have demonstrated that PRRSV infection upregulated the expression of miR-382-5p, which in turn could facilitate PRRSV replication and inhibit the production of type I interferon by targeting HSP60 (Figure 9). And we also found that HSP60 could promote the production of type I interferon, interact with MAVS and inhibit PRRSV replication in a MAVS-dependent manner. These data indicated that miR-382-5p was a host component upregulated by PRRSV to regulate PRRSV replication and HSP60 was a novel antiviral protein against PRRSV.

summary:
Introduction:

Porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV), a small enveloped virus including a single positive-strand RNA genome and belonging to Arteriviridae family,[1] with highest mutant rate of all known RNA viruses,[2] causes reproductive disorders in sows and respiratory distress in piglets and is considered as one of the most economically significant pathogens worldwide.[3].

After the virus invades the cell, the viral nucleic acid and other pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) could be recognized by cellular pattern-recognition receptors (PRRs) such as retinoic acid-inducible gene-I (RIG-I)-like receptors and Toll-Like receptors (TLRs).

TLRs through binding myeloid differentiation factor 88 (MyD88) or Toll/ IL-1 receptor domain-containing adaptor protein inducing IFNβ (TRIF), while RIG-The author ors melanoma differentiation-associated gene 5 (MDA5) via binding to their adaptor protein mitochondrial antiviral signaling protein (MAVS), transmits signals to TANK-binding kinase 1 (TBK1) and the author kappas B kinase ε (IKK-ε).

Type I interferons bind to IFN-α/β r eceptors on the cell surface, causing receptor dimerization, and eventually inducing the production of a large number of IFN-stimulated genes that could inhibit or eliminate the virus.[6,7]

Conclusion:

Introduction: Porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV), a small enveloped virus including a single positive-strand RNA genome and belonging to Arteriviridae family,[1] with highest mutant rate of all known RNA viruses,[2] causes reproductive disorders in sows and respiratory distress in piglets and is considered as one of the most economically significant pathogens worldwide.[3].

After the virus invades the cell, the viral nucleic acid and other pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) could be recognized by cellular pattern-recognition receptors (PRRs) such as retinoic acid-inducible gene-I (RIG-I)-like receptors and Toll-Like receptors (TLRs).

TLRs through binding myeloid differentiation factor 88 (MyD88) or Toll/ IL-1 receptor domain-containing adaptor protein inducing IFNβ (TRIF), while RIG-The author ors melanoma differentiation-associated gene 5 (MDA5) via binding to their adaptor protein mitochondrial antiviral signaling protein (MAVS), transmits signals to TANK-binding kinase 1 (TBK1) and the author kappas B kinase ε (IKK-ε).

Type I interferons bind to IFN-α/β r eceptors on the cell surface, causing receptor dimerization, and eventually inducing the production of a large number of IFN-stimulated genes that could inhibit or eliminate the virus.[6,7]
Conclusion: The main characteristic of PRRSV infection is that it could cause immunosuppression, persistent infection, and secondary infection, resulting in huge economic losses to the pig industry.[43-45].

MiRNAs function as important posttranscriptional regulators and could be as the potential therapeutic targets for disease treatment, so miR-382-5p might be a potential therapeutic target for anti-PRRSV

claims: We found that PRRSV infection upregulated the expression of miR382-5p, which in turn inhibited polyI:C-induced the production of type I interferon by targeting heat shock protein 60 (HSP60), thus facilitating PRRSV replication in MARC-145 cells

Furthermore, we found that HSP60 could interact with mitochondrial antiviral signaling protein (MAVS), an important signal transduction protein for inducing production of type I interferon, and promote polyI:C-mediated the production of type I interferon in a MAVS-dependent manner
We also found that HSP60 could inhibit PRRSV replication in a MAVS-dependent manner, which indicated that HSP60 was a novel antiviral protein against PRRSV replication
In this study, we found that miR-382-5p was upregulated by PRRSV, and could inhibit type I interferon production and promote PRRSV replication
We revealed that HSP60 could positively regulate MAVS-mediated type I IFN signaling and interact with MAVS, and the antiviral activity of HSP60 is dependent on MAVS
And then, we investigated potential target genes of miR-382-5p

MARC-145 cells were transfected with MAVS, p-284, and different concentrations of HSP60, and we found that HSP60 increased MAVS-mediated IFN-β promoter activity (Figure 5G) and the transcriptional levels of IFN-β (Figure 5H) in a dose-dependent manner

In this study, we found that miR-382-5p was upregulated by PRRSV (Figure 1), and acted as a novel miRNA that negatively regulated the production of type I interferon (Figure 3) and promoted PRRSV replication (Figure 2)

The results in the present study showed that the expression levels of miR-382-5p were up-regulated following PRRSV infection, with maximum changes at 24 hours postinfection (Figure 1A), and PRRSV infection increased miR-382-5p expression in a dose-dependent manner in MARC-145 cells (Figure 1B), which indicated that the results about the expression levels of miR-382-5p from previous small RNA deep sequencing may be not correct

We found that overexpression of HSP60 could inhibit PRRSV replication in MARC-145 cells, and knockdown of HSP60 could promote PRRSV replication (Figure 8), which indicated that HSP60 was an antiviral protein against PRRSV replication

We have demonstrated that PRRSV infection upregulated the expression of miR-382-5p, which in turn could facilitate PRRSV replication and inhibit the production of type I interferon by targeting HSP60 (Figure 9)
And we also found that HSP60 could promote the production of type I interferon, interact with MAVS and inhibit PRRSV replication in a MAVS-dependent manner
